awesome video very informative! we have found perfect cubes of this stuff in the abandoned mines we explore. one thing i would like to point out is that the the small shiny pieces in streambeds that people often say is pyrite or fools gold is most likely actually mica. the mineral labeled as pyrite at 3:23 is most likely mica unless the material being panned was just crushed and hasn't been exposed to oxygen but it looks like stream sediment. pyrite tends to rust very easily when exposed to oxygen and even quicker when exposed to water and becomes dull quickly but mica retains its shine forever even as it is broken down in streams to smaller and smaller pieces

I very much like to show one of these perfectly cubic pyrite pieces when people say things like "I hate all these squares, cubes, and straight lines in the city, this is not natural! Nature never creates such things!". Sometimes, when I don't have access to a pyrite like that, I just take a grain of table salt and ask the person to take a very close look at it.

I liked to make iron (II) sulfide, FeS, when I was young, by mixing proper amounts of sulfur powder and iron powder and heating it, the process of which was shown near the end of this video. That process in itself is very interesting; it looks as if the iron is burning with the oxygen in the air, but it is actually directly uniting with the sulfur, no oxygen is needed for this. Anyway, the even more fun part was of course when you took the resulting FeS and poured some hydrochloric acid on it, and got that reaction which produced hydrogen sulfide, H2S, which smelled like rotten eggs. One day I thought that it would be cool if you mixed powderized FeS with an acid that is in the form of a powder, so that no reaction takes place until you pour water on it. I would then have a stink bomb that I could easily "detonate" at will. The only acid that I could think of was citric acid, which my mother had in the kitchen. So I created that mixture and kept it in a small plastic container with a lid. I brought it to a friend of mine, and we decided to take a small local train into Stockholm. In that train we opened the container, poured some water into it, shook it, and put it into one of the trash cans in our wagon. There were other people in the wagon too. Nothing happened, no smell, and I was disappointed and thought that perhaps citric acid was too weak of an acid. We got off the train in Stockholm (the end station), and spent a few hours there having some fun, and then in the afternoon we went back to the station to catch the train back home. We were a bit late so as soon as we entered the wagon the train started to move. The wagon was totally empty, not a single person, and there was a terrible smell of rotten eggs. We had happened to get into the same wagon as we took earlier that day. Our little experiment had actually worked, although very slowly. Fortunately it was possible to walk from one wagon to another, so we quickly went to the next wagon to escape the horrible smell.

Pyrite from the Glendon Pyrophyllite mine in North Carolina ALSO form perfect cubes.  I know because I have mined several from that mine, they had (I dont know if they still do this) open house days at the quarry/mine pit and you could pay to go in and mine the accessory minerals to the pyrophyllite. (mainly huge pyrite cubes and twins, the occasional ultra-rare blue/green fluorite, and some trace iron ore minerals (hematite, magnetite, ilmenite , etc...)  I have one cube from this location that is larger than my fist and damn near perfectly cubic.  It's incredible how heavy it is.  The twins that form here are amazing too, there will be two perfectly formed cubes joined at the most aesthetically pleasing angles.  Pyrite is a fun mineral to hunt.  I also know a much more accessible place to find smaller cubes on highway 321 out of blowing rock NC.  I used to head down to NC all the time to collect minerals, a great state for rockhounds.  Sadly, I don't get down that way very often anymore.

To try and explain the fracturing of the pyrite sample...
When you heat up a mineral the sudden heating can cause deformation or dilation in the crystallography of the mass, and when a large enough temperature gradient exists in the sample, like in very insulative minerals like pyrite, or if the crystallography is just very weak, it causes internal stress to build up inside the sample, as the heated, and thus, dilated crystals separate from the lower temperature, normally sized crystals, or the rapid contraction or dilation just breaks the structure uniformly. This is also why ceramics and glasses crack if you heat them too much. If it gets hot enough, then yes, in some minerals, the crystallography "completely" breaks down, whether it be due to chemical processes, or just physical stress put on the crystallography, resulting in a slew of miniature crystals, usually resembling a powder, seen in the porous iron oxide layer. BTW, many minerals can crystalize into more than one form depending on conditions, and other factors. Calcite has numerous crystal forms, quartz only has one. In this video Marcasite and Pyrite are what we call polymorphs, diamond and graphite are also examples. Same formula but different bonding and arrangement in the crystal lattice.

Actually, you CAN use pyrite's semiconductor properties, you can straight up make a diode with it easily. All you have to do is make contact it with a large surface area piece of metal for one connection, and with the tip of a sharp spike with another piece of metal. This forms what is known as a point contact diode. You can even make a transistor this way, by making contact with 2 different whiskers of metal that are placed really close to each other. This is in fact how the first transistor was made, though it was with a different semiconductor, it wasn't iron sulfide. Early radios often used this method for its rectifier, though they usually used galena, or lead sulfide, which produces superior diodes to iron sulfide.

Im adding this detail since it may add in as a reason why I saw "the gold" inside/in between crevices of the rocks Ive found. So the first rock that Ive found was a part of or debris of the rocky mountains that I mentioned. The rock was pretty solid and had a lot of crevices, the rock had gold like crystals stuck between the crevices, my first thought was gold, it was a lot. I tried taking them off by picking it with a knife, it was hard so i tried breaking it a part with a rock, after a lot of tries I cracked it open, more of it can be seen inside. I showed it to my parents, they told me its not gold. Theyre not experts and so was I, I took their word and just kept the rock. I began to think maybe it was just metal or iron, I knew basic stuff back then since I dreamed of being a scientist and things like those intrigued me, maybe it was oxidized iron and the rocks was rich with iron and all those times within the waters turned it into rust hence looking like gold stuck on the crevices, since a lot of those rocks in the river was sedimentary rocks. As a Geology student, I can give you the simplest explanation for the different shapes of Pyrite and Gold.
You can find Gold in nature as "native": the composition of it is purely Au (charged 0, so elemental form, as found on periodic table); pyrite is a sulfide salt instead (FeS2), so it crystallize, as every other salt, in geometric shapes 😊 in this case, pyrite forms cubes when pressure, concentrations of components and temperature are consistent, and other geometrical shapes when a change in its original contitions happens 😊

Here's another fun fact - when blasting in mines with a lot of pyrite in the ore, the pyrite dust can explode if it happens to get mixed with the right amount of air in what is called a secondary explosion.  This can happen with other airborne dust, like flour.

Not exactly stoichiometric FeS2, more like Fe S(2-x) with x<0.15. Not really important, but to a chemist....?!! The other irony is that many gold deposits are associated with pyrite as the reducing conditions also reduced gold-bearing high-temperature chloride brine believed to the the transport mechanism of certain types of deposits. In the Spanish "Pyrite Belt" there is gold associated with many pyrite deposits often as much as 4 ppm (4 grams per tonne). The colour is not really like gold, chalcopyrite (copper-iron) is more "gold" - yellow, marcasite is too white and pyrrhotite (magnetic) is a more bronze colour.


Finally, gold in quartz veins can and does form small cubic or octahedral crystals, not always amorphous as nuggets are.

Of those who stop partway, some fraction of them will stop somewhere between “you can technically just sniff it” and “same as cyanide gas”. Those people will be left with the WRONG impression of “Oh neat! Furthermore , surprising things are more memorable than unsurprising things, and it seems so surprising to hear you nonchalantly talk about just sniffing it that it’s very memorable. "Iron pyrite" is not longer the correct name. The only approved name is pyrite. Pyrite's similarity to gold, in terms of colour, may also be slightly changed due to partial oxidation that causes ultra-thin oxide-rich layer on the top (to make the mineral more yellow, as opposite to its typical brass colour). Reactions of many minerals with acids will need larger surface area than that represented by large crystals. Grinding these minerals is actually a way of distinguishing some of them (e.g., dolomite against calcite). The red stuff is, indeed, Fe2O3 (a synthetic equivalent of hematite). The sample you have here is actually from pyrite deposit at Navajun in Spain. The rock in which these cubes sit is a talc schist. Btw, a similar mineral that is even more similar to gold in terms of its colour, is chalcopyrite, CuFeS2. It may, however, be quite easily distinguished due to partial coverage of initial oxidation products that, due to the difference of the thin film thickness, are vivid pink, green, or purple.

Cinnabar if you feel like working with mercury, Rutile/Illemite if you want to try and home refine some Titanium to show how tricky it can be, Iron Ferrite and Martensite if want to talk crystal structures and some solubility phase chemistry as topic.

The fragmenting is more likely do to Thermal Stress/Strain, by heating most materials(with a  few exceptions like Carbon Fiber), you get a expansion proportional to the change in temperature and some positive constants(one such constant for length change is alpha), this is strain in engineering and mechanical terms. As result there is stress/strain relationships therein  the change in temperature results you get forces building up inside the object until in this case it shatters under the forces usually around the heating site and weak points/stress concentrations. If heating where slower and more uniform this would be reduced, and the object might successfully change dimensions overall without shattering as more ductile materials tend to(eg if the change in strain and stress where uniform due to uniform heating). It is possible for decomposition and phase changes inside a rock to participate in this, such as if rock is quickly heated with water or ice embedded deep enough the steam can cause cracking as well, so the slight amount of gas produced by this decomposition might be factor, but the Thermal Stress is likely your fundamental culprit. Aggregate and fractured rocks are much more susceptible to the differential stresses and strains on differential heating hence the old warning about campfire and rock selection though cautiously with fast enough intense enough fire almost any rock can produce fragments.

NileRed - I have been watching your vids for a very long time. I can help explain why your cube of iron pyrite kept fracturing with the torch.

The process is called spalling. When you heat a frangible material, it places HUGE strain on it. The expansion rate differs with material, but heating something like this with a fast differential temperature makes the outside expand a couple thousandths of an inch, while the cool side remains constrained. This creates strain in the material, similar to stretching a hardened non-ductile spring. It strains until it snaps, and then that piece gets ejected.

You have to be careful using the word semiconductor, it has two meanings, either the material properties of being of low conductivity, such as FeS2, or in an electronics sense, it can be forced to switch between conductive and near non-conductive states by applying a small voltage at a junction.

Saying that you can just use FeS2 or something similar in a way that is similar to doped silicon is simply wrong.

Two terms, very similar but with two distinct meanings.

1) Semiconductor = poor conductor.
2) Semiconductor = what we use in electronics.

I nearly poisoned myself with H2S sometime between 1964 & 1966.  I was generating H2S using a Kipps Apparatus in the fume cupboard at school (perhaps to test for Lead, Silver or Mercury in an inorganic salt).  I had become used to the smell when suddenly I began to choke on the gas.  I quickly moved away from the fume hood and recovered in a minute or so.  I also killed a wasp's nest with H2S once, but the wasps became angry and I got stung several times.  There was no health and safety in those days and I remember the first experiment we were given to do.  Each student had a semi-micro tube with a little mercury oxide at the bottom.  We heated the tube and the salt changed from red to yellow (or vice versa - I can't remember which) then little globules of mercury formed on the sides of the test-tube.  A wonderful introduction to Chemistry.

Stilbite or other zeolites would be interesting to hear about. They're structurally one of the most interesting silicates, with a very complex hydration quality leading to their use in drying agents. Their porous nature is also interesting as a filter for the petroleum industry. Catalysis through surface adsorption is also very interesting, and the ability to separate rare earth metals based on pore size for purification from thorium reactors and/or compression to create a safer radioisotope enriched glass for safer disposal is also very interesting. Good video overall as well, I feel like pyrite is one of the common minerals that fascinates everybody as a child. Seeing this just increased my appreciation of its value as a resource and general mineral specimen. Mineral chemistry and physics doesn't seem to garner as much attention as it should considering the incredible ways they're used. That being said, it'd also really nice to see a video on calcite. The optics of calcite and its general use in nature in shells, skeletons, and other common uses are very widespread and extremely fascinating. This would be a very good example to highlight the nature of reflective indices and birefringence to tie in some valueable physics relations to the nature of light-matter interactions. Thanks again for the video and all others you've made. Your content is some of the most important as far as general open access teaching is concerned on this platform in my opinion.

you explain the chipping of pyrite while warming due to the chemical decomposition and than resulting increased inner gas pressure. 6:40

But have you thought about thermal stresses, that result in material failure? Pyrite is quite brittle and it does not only crack at the hot spots, but even in spots where pyrite could not have been at its decomposition temperature. Since, pyrite is a bad conductor, it would make sense to also be a bad thermal conductor, which would mean that it had big temperature gradients and thus because it tends to expand more than copper on heat (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF03048745) you get big strains, which result in big stresses and parts chipping away.

This theory would also make sense to the fact, that you smaller block does not break apart anymore. You heated that on more sides, so the temperatur got more evened out. Also the block is smaller, which means, that the temperaute gradient was propably smaller too. Or in other words. Maybe try heating the pyrite slower and more uniform.
